snippet.textDisplay: This was one of the games I was most looking forward to when it was announced and honestly it did not disappoint. The combat is fun, the builds and armor sets with the different bonuses work really well together and keep the combat interesting, I love the cellshading art style and although the difficulty of the bosses gets harder as you progress it always feel rewarding when you get them down. Overall I highly recommend it for those that enjoy souls like games and well worth the money.

snippet.textDisplay:
Every enemy relies on near-identical attack chains with variations of delay and attack number combined with perfect tracking and outright teleporting.
Everything is the second Gundyr fight from DS3.  I liked him then as a novelty challenge, but a whole game of it is tiresome.
In DS you get better with each encounter.  In Khazan you tediously learn each boss's entire moveset and the correct responses.
snippet.textOriginal:
Every enemy relies on near-identical attack chains with variations of delay and attack number combined with perfect tracking and outright teleporting.
Everything is the second Gundyr fight from DS3.  I liked him then as a novelty challenge, but a whole game of it is tiresome.
In DS you get better with each encounter.  In Khazan you tediously learn each boss's entire moveset and the correct responses.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm in the minority to say that this "tough as f#$k" games are becoming the new gaming trend. Not everybody has the time to grind in sweaty lobbies or spend 10 hours with literally ZERO progression in a game. It's stupid. Same goes for "oh...its 100 hours long" BS. With a huge backlog of games in my Steam library, I don't want to fight every imaginary wall in the game to unlock a secret item or spend days in a single area without any real progress. Even for RPG, my sweet spot is around 20-30 hours. Or maybe I'm getting too old for gaming.

snippet.textDisplay: This is one of the few soulslikes that i refuse to use summons. I didn't summon in ds3, nioh 1&2 (i don't remember if you can even summon in the nioh games) and now khazan. snippet.textDisplay:
Probably the first time I got 100% on a game before you. Really REALLY enjoyed the combat in this game, everything else felt kinda meh to me. Story was god awful but I wasn't expecting anything different. Environments and enemy variety was pretty lackluster as well. The hub area and the inability to directly teleport from one "bonfire" to another one were some really apparent QoL issues that I'm surprised the developers didn't think of. Not a fan of the Nioh type loot system. Not a fan of the Nioh type mission system. 
BUT... the bosses and the combat were so friggin good it made the game super enjoyable! Probably the best combat I've experienced in a Souls-like game.

Probably the first time I got 100% on a game before you. Really REALLY enjoyed the combat in this game, everything else felt kinda meh to me. Story was god awful but I wasn't expecting anything different. Environments and enemy variety was pretty lackluster as well. The hub area and the inability to directly teleport from one "bonfire" to another one were some really apparent QoL issues that I'm surprised the developers didn't think of. Not a fan of the Nioh type loot system. Not a fan of the Nioh type mission system. 
BUT... the bosses and the combat were so friggin good it made the game super enjoyable! Probably the best combat I've experienced in a Souls-like game.

I understand Nioh didn't launch with an endgame either, but like if these games want to do the whole infinite loot grind thing from diablo, they should have high difficulty late game content to let you farm gear and put your build to the test. snippet.textDisplay:
If you enjoyed this game, I strongly recommend trying Final Fantasy Origin: Stranger of Paradise. Awful writing aside: the combat and bosses feel almost identical to First Berserker in the best way.

The games have a ton of push forward focus on combat, encouraging you to be aggressive with a ton of abilities, poise and parties at your disposal. Honestly it‚Äôs one of the most underrated souls-likes, I wish more people gave it a shot. I greatly enjoyed getting the platinum trophy for it.

snippet.textDisplay: The best action game I've ever played. Not even kidding. It just feels perfect for my preferences! I've played most "soulslikes" that are on PC except for Nioh games and I'm quite excited to play them in the future. The reason why I love Khazan so much is the parry system - same reason I loved Sekiro so much. So maybe Nioh won't hit the exact points Khazan and Sekiro hit for me, but I'm excited! I much much much much much prefer Sekiro and Khazan to games like Elden Ring (which I platinumed on Steam and I definitely enjoyed, but not for combat reasons specifically)

snippet.textDisplay:
Khazan is a fun character in the DFO lore because he's already dead before the game starts but he's the sole reason an entire playable class (with 4 subclasses) exists due to him starting the Khazan Syndrome where people can be born with a possessed arm. You don't really learn much about him in the story either, just that he was betrayed and that he was best buddies with Ozma, and then you spend far more time learning about Ozma and his fight with Saint Michael rather than learning anything about Khazan.
I'm excited to play this eventually, DFO was THE MMO before FFXIV for me.

snippet.textDisplay: I tried the demo, but to be honest, "Sekiro" made most of the other soulslikes I've played feel uninspired and rather clunky. Even P feels somehow tankier to control as opposed to Wolf, let alone Khazan who's supposed to be a sort of in-your-face, brutish warrior. If you've played "NiOH", "Thymesia" or "Lords of the Fallen" and liked them, then you're probably going to like this.
